<extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> might repress the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter , either through direct physical contact with the promoter or by regulating intermediates affecting the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter .

To investigate whether <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is directly associated with the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter , we first performed electrophoretic mobility shift assays ( EMSA ) using a <extra_id_0> c-Myc <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - tagged <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in a reticulocyte lysate-based transcription / translation in vitro system .
The probes used are listed in Figure 3A .
The 36 - base pair ( bp ) WT probe corresponds to the critical region of the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter defined in our promoter deletion analyses .
This probe contains two consensus Sox / Sox6 binding sites .
Also included in our EMSA are three mutated probes that are , either truncated ( M1 ) , or mutated ( M2 and M3 ) in Sox / Sox6 binding sites ( Figure 3A ) .

<extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is able to physically associate with the 36 - bp region ( Figure 3B ) within the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter defined by the deletion analysis experiments ( Figure 2C ) .
The 36 - bp probe was shifted by the tagged <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein .

Moreover , both <extra_id_0> c-Myc <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antibodies supershift the band , indicating that the binding is <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - specific .

To rule out the possibility that the <extra_id_0> c-Myc <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> tag itself binds to the probe , an <extra_id_0> HA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - tagged <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was used in another EMSA that confirmed these results ( Figure 3C ) .
Next , nuclear extracts from MEL cells were used in EMSA employing the same 36 - bp probe .
MEL cells , a murine erythroleukemic cell line , express adult <extra_id_0> beta globins <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , but not <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 33 ] .
<extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> directly binds to this DNA sequence in MEL cells ( Figure 3D ) .
The intact consensus Sox / Sox6 binding sites of the DNA probe are required for the binding , as shown in the competition assay ( Figure 3E ) .
Ablation of putative Sox / Sox6 binding sites ( M1 and M3 ) abolish their ability to compete in EMSA ( Figure 3E ) .
The M2 mutant probe may compete partially with WT binding .

To investigate the functional significance of the intact Sox / Sox6 binding sites , the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter reporter constructs with mutagenized Sox / Sox6 binding sites were co-transfected with the <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> overexpression vector into GM979 cells .

Consistent with the EMSA results , the mutant <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter reporter constructs ( with either one or both Sox / Sox6 binding sites mutagenized ) do not result in significant promoter repression in transfection studies ( Figure 3F ) .
Thus , both sites are required for maximal repression of <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> by <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , but not to the same degree .

We also tested whether <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binds to the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter in vivo using chromatin immunoprecipitation ( ChIP ) ( Figure 4 ) .

The <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - containing complex was immunoprecipitated from MEL cells or from liver cells of 15.5 dpc WT mice using <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antibody .

Figure 4 shows that the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> proximal promoter is readily immunoprecipitated with <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antibody in both MEL cells and liver cells .
Normal IgG was used as a negative control ( Figure 4A ) .

The above data ( Figures 3 and 4 ) clearly indicate that <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> acts as a repressor of the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene by directly binding to the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter , probably as a dimer .
